content: Sapper is also a word for combat engineer from the days when "sapping" was employing trenches ("saps") to provide a covered approach to defences during siege work and "to sap" was the act of digging a sap. Sapper is also the title of a fully trained private soldier in British and Commonwealth Royal Engineer corps.

content: The non-derogatory nickname for the Royal Engineers is the Sappers in the same way that the Royal Artillery are the Gunners (of course as the two corps were very closely related for several hundred years as part of the Board of Ordnance their nicknames for one another are derogatory). Most British regiments and corps try to avoid calling their privates "private" if they can, it's one of the ways of inculcating the esprit de corps (read: tribalism) that the Army runs on. The word is from the Italian for spadework, zappa via the French sape (French sapeurs btw, like British infantry Pioneer Sergeants would be anathema to the US Army because they tend to have impressive beards).
